stance_justification: The writer consistently treats all choices as equally valid personal preferences without evaluating their relative merits. They explicitly state 'There's no right or wrong way for all of this to go down' and frame all outcomes as equally acceptable ('Your first relationship might be phenomenal, and it might be a total dud. And either way, that's life'). The advice centers on personal choice without criteria for making better decisions.
stance_markers: ["There's no formula that says you must", "so do what feels right for you", "There's no right or wrong way for all of this to go down", "Your first relationship might be phenomenal, and it might be a total dud. And either way, that's life", "It will happen in its own course", "that's okay"]
text: Cheers. And I'm not saying don't have a casual fling if the opportunity presents itself and that's what you want, but also don't feel pressure to settle if you'd rather hold out for something better. There's no formula that says you must hook up by X age or sleep with Y number of partners. These things vary a LOT (and don't assume that other people talking about their "numbers" are being honest either), so do what feels right for you. I'll tell you my first time was lame as shit. I thought it was just something I needed to get over with because of my age, and it sucked. Loads of people end up feeling that way. I don't beat myself up about it, but I'm not proud of it either. Know what I mean? There's no right or wrong way for all of this to go down. Your first relationship might be phenomenal, and it might be a total dud. And either way, that's life. You'll be just fine. It's hard at your age, but try not to build it up in your head. There will be a first time, and there will be times after that. It will happen in its own course. It (probably) won't be the earth-shattering event you thought it would be, and that's okay. That's why I say keep working on yourself. Take care of yourself, and maintain other interests. Ten years from now you will look back and laugh at your younger self, I promise. For now, just enjoy the ride.

stance_justification: The writer consistently frames all approaches to friendship as equally valid without evaluating their relative merits. They use pure relativistic language like 'There isn't a right "meter"' and 'There isn't a "right" way to be friends' and defer all judgment to personal fit ('find someone that fits with you'). Rather than weighing different friendship approaches, they present contradictory advice (being available vs. not being too available) without acknowledging the tension.
stance_markers: ["There isn't a right \"meter\"", "There isn't a \"right\" way to be friends", "find someone that fits with you", "only he doesn't fit with you", "Look for someone that fits with you", "It's normal", "it's okay"]
text:
In my experience, if you make friends... you will realize that they have their lives too, and their lives and facts are often more important than being available or worried for you. It's normal to be a friend, and having a life; it's okay if you want to pass some time alone, if you wish time to care for yourself. There isn't a right "meter", to establish how much time you need. There isn't a "right" way to be friends, if you are loyal; do not feel guilt, you have just to find someone that fits with you and have similar needs.

It happens also that if you are too much focused on being "available" for your friends, therefore you become angry when they aren't available for you, so you become "selfish" in another way.

Do not worry, and please understand that it's not entirely up to you. You are only half responsible for the success of your friendship. Even if someone dislikes your "friendship style", only he doesn't fit with you. Look for someone that fits with you... At least to begin.

stance_justification: The writer explicitly frames their advice as personal opinion ('just my opinion') and emphasizes that 'nothing I say is an absolute' and 'what's right for one person isn't for another.' They present their perspective without attempting to justify why it might be better than alternatives, instead deferring entirely to individual preference and experience.
stance_markers: ["just my opinion", "nothing I say is an absolute", "What's right for one person isn't for another", "I'm just speaking from my point of view of life and experience"]
text:
Hi, I think a lot of people are feeling this way. Not just this group! There's a sort of release of tension, because we're not in situations where we feel we have to respond and more importantly, where we'll feel judged.

I think eventually, you and others will want to get out and work at feeling comfortable in company.

But right now, for so many of us, it's like a huge weight taken off our back. 

While I think it's great to allow ourselves to feel this relief (which may be a new sensation) I think it's important... just my opinion... that we enjoy it now with the realization that at the right moment we will strive to be able to feel the same or some of the level of comfort we feel alone, with other people.

Please note, nothing I say is an absolute! What's right for one person isn't for another. I'm just speaking from my point of view of life and experience.

If someone asks why you‚Äôre being quiet just be totally honest, but polite/friendly. I just told them ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have anything to really add to the conversation‚Äù. If you‚Äôre confident with who you are, which is a quiet person, then embrace it and try not to worry about it. stance_justification: The writer explicitly defers evaluation at the outset ('I'm not going to explain how you should do it, since everyone has their own ways') and consistently treats all approaches as equally valid without weighing their relative merits. They acknowledge individual differences ('Everyone is different. They have different people they prefer to hang out with') but don't evaluate which strategies might be more effective in different situations.
stance_markers: ["everyone has their own ways", "Everyone is different", "They have different people they prefer to hang out with", "depending on the person", "That's just my to go advice"]
text:
that's fine, I'm not going to explain how you should do it, since everyone has their own ways.  But i'll give you my detail of some people i started knowing in my classes and how i met them.  Usually the people in my class whether they are a little bit further away or next to me.  The ones next to you are easier because they're next to you and you can just make a small conversation of like.  How did you do on the exam? or How was the homework?  Eventually you guys can lead to small subjects.  I sometimes compliment them on something if I really mean it.  Don't do it just to compliment but if you actually mean it, it has a bigger effect.  This girl I remember we just talked about school most the time.  I usually ask oh you taking any other classes besides this?  What's your major?  IF they're undecided, i usually say something to uplift them like im sure you'll find out what you want to do.  There is something you like to do right? :)  

I mostly talk about them and what they're into.  If you notice they seem to be a little bit annoyed then its time to back away.  You don't want to be the pushy interrogation guy.  You just want to know enough, and let it be.  Let them talk to you again instead.  Start over the next day.  Good morning or hows it going *name*.  How's ur day been?  and you can reset it again.  After a while you guys get used to each other depending on the person.  Everyone is different.  They have different people they prefer to hang out with.  My group around me we hung out together during the breaks of our classes because it was a Lab.  And we talked to each other because we needed help.  We ended up asking for each other's facebook.  And was like hey, what's do you got a facebook?  We could help each other on the work if anything.  That's just my to go advice.  Good luck!

stance_justification: The writer repeatedly frames their advice as personal opinion that the reader can freely accept or reject, using phrases like 'these are just my thoughts, you don't have to accept it' and 'you can just close this comment and move on.' They share personal experiences without claiming these approaches will work for others, and explicitly avoid making evaluative judgments about what the reader should do.
stance_markers: ["these are just my thoughts, you don't have to accept it", "you can just unlike it or delete it even, I dont mind", "I just said my experiences and my opinions", "Again, I am not saying that you should accept this as it is", "you can just close this comment and move on with something else if you want", "it is completely up to you", "if this helps you in any way I am happy, if it didn't, well maybe someone else might be able to try and help you"]
text:
Hey man. I just wish you would take time and read this completely because I feel it's going to be a little long. Firstly, I am sorry for what you are going through and I hope you will find what you are looking for. **Disclaimer: these are just my thoughts, you don't have to accept it, you can just unlike it or delete it even, I dont mind.** And also I am younger than you and I feel like I have my shares of loneliness (no friends I could share my deepest secrets, just friends in names, there are nobody I have nearby that I could share my interests with, I don't hang out with anyone in my own class and I might be like a shadow lol) and I am not saying that I know exactly what you are going through because that doesn't bring justice to what you are going through as I don't know if it is the same as me.

First of all I am not going to give you false hopes saying that it is going to work out if you think that people love you and stuff. But that is a part of it. Just have positive thoughts. And you know how you could be positive? Here's what I figured would kick-start us to be positive. I started to find things that made me curious and exciting, and I work on that. I was lucky to have found out my interest at a young age (I am still young by the way :P lol) and I am intending to take it as my career. I realized this recently as I was really depressed for maybe two months and this week I found something that is in my interest and I started working on it by creating a small goal. I was happy to be able to be consistent with it and working on it. I get excited when I see that I am progressing little by little. Also, I enjoy the working part more than seeing my goal accomplished. But I also know that if I drop this goal at some point, depression will be back in the house. That's why I am trying very careful not to be burnout and try to complete it, so I get an accomplished feeling and use that for the next thing I might be doing. 

I believe that there are many things that as an individual we are interested in it and I don't think that there is a magical destiny for each of us or magical talent that we need to discover inside us blah blah blah. So just give a thought in what you are interested in and try to work in it. It doesn't matter, it can be anything. Painting, dancing, music, instrument, programming, tinkering with gadgets, designing, martial arts etc. etc. And you know what, maybe you might find people who share the same interests as you, and you might hit it really well. Try being curious like a kid and explore - that's what I will say.

Also, another thing I will give a lot of credit to in my life was when I started to meditate. Well it's not when I started, it was maybe a long time after I started, like three months after I started. That's when the effects of my daily-two-times-15minutes-meditation started to kick in. At the beginning I was like "what is this, will it ever work?", well I was really convinced when I started to experience the true results. It will take time for some to see the effect of meditation. For some it will be really quick. Fact is, it doesn't matter what the result is, just do it for the sake of doing it. 

Enjoy the path to your destination rather than waiting for the goal to complete to celebrate. Celebrate every day. Who cares if someone ignores me. I like it when I work on the stuff I like ü•≥ yay. This is my current state. Me, who was just one week ago, was trying to think I might be alone for my whole life started to think that maybe I will see someone who have same interests as me. **Again, I am not saying that you should accept this as it is, you can just close this comment and move on with something else if you want and just forget what I said, it is completely up to you.** Everyday something good might happen, something bad might happen. It might be the best day some days. It might be the worst day some days that you feel like why go on more. But who cares if it is a bad day, **let it go**, it doesn't matter in the end.

I just said my experiences and my opinions and the way I tried to tackle my loneliness. I might not have tackled my loneliness, but oh well I got at least my parents who do take care of me, and now I am realizing that there were people who have actually cared about me at some point. I don't think I have to try to tackle my loneliness, I think I have to change my attention to something else. Sorry for making it so long, if this helps you in any way I am happy, if it didn't, well maybe someone else might be able to try and help you. I didn't mean to offend you in any way, if you feel like that anywhere.

stance_markers: ["Whether this is right for you personally is your choice, which much be respected", "depends on your wanting to integrate", "Whether this is helpful or not depends on", "Identity is a complex issue"]
text: I definitely see your point on having a static stereotype of the modern male, and I think the needing to be an "alpha male" or whatever that means is definitely a negative consequence of mainstream media and advertising.  But this article I would argue is not deeming the only way to have a confident identity (whether that be masculine or otherwise) as being a fixed set of principles which I would disagree with. Its just giving pointers of qualities that are socially norm for what confidence is considered as. Whether this is helpful or not depends on your wanting to integrate in what the current definition of society is. Whether this is right for you personally is your choice, which much be respected. But for those who do want to be more extroverted in this way I personally believe the article can benefit them . Identity is a complex issue.  But thanks for reading and writing your thoughts :)

stance_justification: The writer explicitly states that 'neither way of communicating is right or wrong, it's just different' and refuses to evaluate which approach might be more effective in different contexts. They present the conflict as simply a matter of different communication styles without weighing the merits of directness versus indirectness, treating both as equally valid approaches that just need accommodation.
stance_markers: ["neither way of communicating is 'right' or 'wrong', it's just different", "it's just different", "taking the attitude that the other person's way of communicating is 'wrong'", "the one who's 'wrong' needs to learn the 'right' way"]
text:
I know EXACTLY what you mean! I have the same problem with a lot people, especially my family. My Mother felt that being direct was low-class. For example: if you're offered something to eat/ drink that you don't like, you're to say " No thank you, I don't care for any. " because it could be thought that you just don't want any. When I asked her why I couldn't just say I don't like it, she told me that it just wasn't done. You weren't allowed to do that if you were a person of 'refinement'. ( rolling my eyes and shaking my head)

I've thought about this very subject and I came to the conclusion that my way of thinking was like being visually impaired; my family is like a hearing impaired person who can only understand sign language. When I hear someone near me, I vocalize. I can't see so I don't realize that they are signing to me. They don't realize that I can't see so they keep signing more and I keep vocalizing louder, and so it goes.

For the record: neither way of communicating is 'right' or 'wrong', it's just different. Somehow or another, there has to be a way for both parties to communicate and be heard.And it isn't going to happen if we keep doing what we're doing and taking the attitude that the other person's way of communicating is 'wrong' and that the the one who's 'wrong' needs to learn the 'right' way.

Again for the record: I expect the program to show me the scenes that are important to the understanding of the story. I've not seen the program, but I agree with the OP of this subject.

text: I'm probably really not helping. But I understand what others mean with "People often comment on how very theoretical I speak", because the way you type this question also comes over to me like that. It doesn't sound natural to me and very business-like or robotic, with a complexity that most people don't use. And it's not the way "common folk" speak. It's probably just the way you were raised or something, and it's just the way you are, and probably very hard or impossible to change that. But that's just my opinion, and I'm also not native English so maybe that could also be a reason for me to think that.
